page.title: 01Moors East of Osmotherley
page.content: The overwhelming impression of this National Park land is of a vast open space covered in heather. There are softly undulating hills to the north west where sheep wander freely, and pheasants, grouse and partridges seek cover from the shooting parties, and V shaped valleys with steams to the south east.A few farms are also in the south east of the block and here the majority of the enclosed grazing for sheep and cattle is to be found. Game birds are very common in this region,also and grouse butts are scattered throughout most of the heather coverd moors. There is one mostly unfenced, minor road across the south pf the block. and a private road in the south east corner, heading north to the farms and shooting lodges up the valley. Also in south east are conifer plantations
